a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [2, 1, 0]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 0, 1]"
and h2 : "c = vector [1, -2, -3]"
shows  "(crossproduct a b) crossproduct c - crossproduct a (crossproduct b c) = vector [6, 3, 0]"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix},$ $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix},$ and $\mathbf{c} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix},$ compute
\[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} - \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}).\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 We have that \begin{align} (\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} &= \left( \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \end{align}and \begin{align} \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) &= \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \left( \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \right) \\
 &= \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}Hence, \[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} - \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}}.\]The main point of this exercise is to illustrate that in general, \[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} \neq \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}).\]In other words, the cross product is not associative.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [2, 1, 0]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 0, 1]"
and h2 : "c = vector [1, -2, -3]"
shows  "(crossproduct a b) crossproduct c - crossproduct a (crossproduct b c) = vector [6, 3, 0]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given vectors a = [2, 1, 0], b = [0, 0, 1], and c = [1, -2, -3], find the vector resulting from the operation "(a cross b) cross c - a cross (b cross c)". The final answer is the vector [6, 3, 0].

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [2, 1, 0]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 0, 1]"
and h2 : "c = vector [1, -2, -3]"
shows  "cross (cross a b) c - cross a (cross b c) = vector [6, 3, 0]"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix},$ $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix},$ and $\mathbf{c} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix},$ compute
\[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} - \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}).\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 We have that \begin{align} (\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} &= \left( \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \end{align}and \begin{align} \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) &= \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \left( \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \right) \\
 &= \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}Hence, \[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} - \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}}.\]The main point of this exercise is to illustrate that in general, \[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} \neq \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}).\]In other words, the cross product is not associative.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [2, 1, 0]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 0, 1]"
and h2 : "c = vector [1, -2, -3]"
shows  "cross (cross a b) c - cross a (cross b c) = vector [6, 3, 0]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given three vectors $a = [2, 1, 0]$, $b = [0, 0, 1]$, and $c = [1, -2, -3]$, calculate the cross product of the cross product of $a$ and $b$ with $c$ and subtract the cross product of $a$ with the cross product of $b$ and $c$. The final answer should be the vector $[6, 3, 0]$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes a b c :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [2,1,0]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0,0,1]"
and h2 : "c = vector [1,-2,-3]"
shows  "(crossproduct a b) crossproduct c - crossproduct a (crossproduct b c) = vector [6,3,0]"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix},$ $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix},$ and $\mathbf{c} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix},$ compute
\[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} - \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}).\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 We have that \begin{align} (\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} &= \left( \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \end{align}and \begin{align} \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) &= \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \left( \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \right) \\
 &= \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}Hence, \[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} - \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}}.\]The main point of this exercise is to illustrate that in general, \[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} \neq \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}).\]In other words, the cross product is not associative.
 *)

theorem 
fixes a b c :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [2,1,0]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0,0,1]"
and h2 : "c = vector [1,-2,-3]"
shows  "(crossproduct a b) crossproduct c - crossproduct a (crossproduct b c) = vector [6,3,0]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given three vectors a, b, and c in 3-dimensional space with a = [2, 1, 0], b = [0, 0, 1], and c = [1, -2, -3], calculate the difference between the cross product of the cross product of a and b with c, and the cross product of a with the cross product of b and c. The final answer is the vector [6, 3, 0].

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [2, 1, 0]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 0, 1]"
and h2 : "c = vector [1, -2, -3]"
shows  "cross (cross a b) c - cross a (cross b c) = vector [6, 3, 0]"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix},$ $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix},$ and $\mathbf{c} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix},$ compute
\[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} - \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}).\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 We have that \begin{align} (\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} &= \left( \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \end{align}and \begin{align} \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) &= \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \left( \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \right) \\
 &= \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}Hence, \[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} - \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}}.\]The main point of this exercise is to illustrate that in general, \[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} \neq \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}).\]In other words, the cross product is not associative.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [2, 1, 0]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 0, 1]"
and h2 : "c = vector [1, -2, -3]"
shows  "cross (cross a b) c - cross a (cross b c) = vector [6, 3, 0]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given the vectors a = [2, 1, 0], b = [0, 0, 1], and c = [1, -2, -3], calculate the cross product of a and b, and then the cross product of that result with c. Subtract from that the cross product of a with the cross product of b and c. The final result should be the vector [6, 3, 0].

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [2,1,0]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0,0,1]"
and h2 : "c = vector [1,-2,-3]"
shows  "(crossprod a b) \<times> c - a \<times> (crossprod b c) = vector [6, 3, 0]"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix},$ $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix},$ and $\mathbf{c} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix},$ compute
\[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} - \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}).\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 We have that \begin{align} (\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} &= \left( \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \end{align}and \begin{align} \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) &= \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \left( \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \right) \\
 &= \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}Hence, \[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} - \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}}.\]The main point of this exercise is to illustrate that in general, \[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} \neq \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}).\]In other words, the cross product is not associative.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [2,1,0]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0,0,1]"
and h2 : "c = vector [1,-2,-3]"
shows  "(crossprod a b) \<times> c - a \<times> (crossprod b c) = vector [6, 3, 0]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given three vectors: a = [2,1,0], b = [0,0,1], and c = [1,-2,-3], calculate the difference between the cross product of a and b with c and the cross product of a with the cross product of b and c. The result is the vector [6, 3, 0].

theorem

assumes h0 : "a = vector [2, 1, 0]"

(* ### Problem

 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [2, 1, 0]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 0, 1]"
and h2 : "c = vector [1, -2, -3]"
shows  "(cross a b) cross c - cross a (cross b c) = vector [6, 3, 0]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given vectors $a = [2, 1, 0]$, $b = [0, 0, 1]$, and $c = [1, -2, -3]$. Compute the difference between the cross product of $a$ and $b$, then cross product with $c$, and the cross product of $a$ with the cross product of $b$ and $c$. The result is the vector $[6, 3, 0]$.

theorem
fixes a b c :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [2,1,0]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0,0,1]"

shows  "(crossproduct a b) crossproduct c - crossproduct a (crossproduct b c) = vector [6,3,0]"

 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [2,1,0]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0,0,1]"
and h2 : "c = vector [1,-2,-3]"
shows  "(crossproduct a b) crossproduct c - crossproduct a (crossproduct b c) = vector [6,3,0]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given vectors a = [2,1,0], b = [0,0,1], and c = [1,-2,-3], calculate the cross product of a and b and then take the cross product of the result with c. Subtract this from the cross product of a with the cross product of b and c. The final answer should be the vector [6,3,0].

theorem
fixes a b c :: "real^3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [2,1,0]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0,0,1]"
and h2 : "c = vector [1,-2,-3]"
shows  "(cross a b) \<times> c - cross a (cross b c) = vector [6,3,0]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given the vectors a = [2,1,0], b = [0,0,1], and c = [1,-2,-3], calculate the vector triple product (a x b) x c - a x (b x c). The final result should be the vector [6,3,0].

theorem

assumes h0 : "a = vector [2, 1, 0]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 0, 1]"
and h2 : "c = vector [1, -2, -3]"
shows  "(crossproduct a b) \<times> c - a \<times> (crossproduct b c) = vector [6, 3, 0]"

(* ### Problem
 Given $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix},$ $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix},$ and $\mathbf{c} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix},$ compute
\[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} - \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}).\] The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 We have that \begin{align} (\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} &= \left( \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \right) \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \end{align}and \begin{align} \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) &= \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \left( \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \right) \\
 &= \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}Hence, \[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} - \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}}.\]The main point of this exercise is to illustrate that in general, \[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} \neq \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}).\]In other words, the cross product is not associative.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: "real ^ 3"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [2, 1, 0]"
and h1 : "b = vector [0, 0, 1]"
and h2 : "c = vector [1, -2, -3]"
shows  "(crossproduct a b) \<times> c - a \<times> (crossproduct b c) = vector [6, 3, 0]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given vectors a = [2, 1, 0], b = [0, 0, 1], and c = [1, -2, -3], find the vector result of the operation "(a cross b) cross c - a cross (b cross c)". The final result should be the vector [6, 3, 0].

natural solution: &= \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \times \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}Hence, \[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} - \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}}.\]The main point of this exercise is to illustrate that in general, \[(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \times \mathbf{c} \neq \mathbf{a} \times (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}).\]In other words, the cross product is not associative.
